Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: A Unified System Theoretic Framework for Cyber Attack-Resilient Power Grid

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: The electric power grid is a complex cyber-physical system, whose reliable and secure operation is of paramount importance to national security and economic vitality. There is a growing and evolving threat of cyber-based attacks, both in numbers and sophistication, on the nation's critical infrastructure. Therefore, cyber security "encompassing attack prevention, detection, mitigation, and resilience" is critical in today's power grid and the emerging smart grid. The goal of this project is to develop a unified system-theoretic framework and analytical tools for cyber-physical security of power systems, capturing the dynamics of the physical system as well as that of the cyber system. Research tasks include: 1) Development of a methodology for impact analysis that includes systematic identification of worst-case stealthy attacks on the power system's wide-area control and evaluating the resulting consequences in terms of stability violations and performance loss. 2) Development of robust cyber-physical countermeasures, employing a combination of methods from system theory, cyber security, and model-based/data-driven tools, in the form of domain-specific anomaly detection/tolerance algorithms and attack-resilient control algorithms. 3) Evaluating the effectiveness of the proposed impact modeling and mitigation algorithms through a combination of simulation and testbed-based evaluations, using realistic system topologies and attack scenarios. The project makes significant contributions to enhance the security and resiliency of the power grid and lays a scientific foundation for cyber-physical security of critical infrastructure. Also, the project develops novel curriculum modules, mentors graduate and undergraduate students including under-represented minorities, leverages industrial collaborations, and exposes high school students to cyber security concepts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The project has resulted in the discovery of a systematic framework for the modeling, impact characterization, and mitigation of attacks in network power systems. In particular, we discovered an uncertainty-based framework involving deterministic (norm-bounded) and stochastic uncertainty for the modeling of malicious attacks in network power system. The proposed framework was used to analyze the vulnerability of both the static and dynamic models in network power systems. We analyzed the vulnerability of wide area monitoring, protection, and control (WAMPAC) system from measurement-based attack from Phasor Measurement Units (PMUs) using dynamic power system models.  The impact characterization was based on stability violations caused by such attacks on the measurement system. The developed results allow us to identify critical PMUs most vulnerable to data integrity attacks and provide a systematic framework for the design of controllers robust to such data integrity attacks. These theoretical advancements towards the cyber security of power system are made possible by fundamental contributions made in the area of stochastic stability analysis and control design of network dynamical systems. Similarly, game-theoretic and robust optimization-based tools were used for the modeling of attacks on the static optimal power flow problem.  Theoretical advancements made by the PI in the solution of the non-convex robust optimization problem are used to analyze the vulnerability of optimal power flow (OPF) to attacks arising from tampering of the system loads and network topology. The results provide a systematic approach for identifying the vulnerability of power system from controllable loads and also revealed the fragile nature of decentralized control problems in power systems. Furthermore, we analyzed the vulnerability of wide area control algorithms, such as the Automatic Generation Control, from the cybersecurity perspective and characterized the impact of frequency stability under data integrity attacks and denial of service attacks. We developed a model-based mitigation algorithm, that leverage load forecast, to mitigate such attacks. The effectiveness of the mitigation algorithm as well as impact characterization under several stealthy attack scenarios were evaluated using Iowa State’s PowerCyber CPS security testbed. Data-driven tools involving transfer operator theoretic methods were developed to understand causal interaction in a dynamical network system. Novel information transfer-based measure is discovered to infer causal interaction in a dynamical system with application to identifying the source and cause of instability in network power system.

This research has also helped the development of a theoretical framework, together with computational tools, for optimal link removals for controllability degradation in dynamical networks, optimal sensor placement for mitigation of vulnerabilities to cyber attacks, and optimal design of sensor collaboration strategies and schedules for network monitoring. We also considered a class of dynamical Boolean networks in which nodes/agents take binary 0-1 values. Such networks have been widely used to model cascading failures, where each node is either healthy or has failed. We used Boolean polynomials to develop a theoretical framework for the analysis and synthesis of such networks. It is expected that theoretical methods from robust optimization will allow the tractable design of networks that are resilient against cascading failures.

 

Broader Impact: The systematic theoretical and computational framework developed in this proposal for stochastic stability analysis and robust control design of network dynamical system will apply to understand stability problem in power system with stochastic renewable uncertainty. The advancement made in the solution of non-convex robust optimization problem can be used to provide an optimal global solution of OPF problem in the presence of renewable uncertainty. The novel approach developed for solving robust optimization problem can be employed to provide a real-time distributed algorithm for a robust optimization problem. Data-driven methods discovered in this proposal for inferring causal interaction from time-series data can be used for network topology identification. The models, algorithms, and experimental scenarios developed within the testbed environment were integrated into a graduate course on CPS security for the smart grid, the same modules were broadly disseminated for research and educational uses beyond Iowa State University. Several graduate students were trained using the testbed environment and also field trips for high school students were hosted (multiple instances) providing them exposure to cybersecurity.
